I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) operationalize Strategy 2030 for its developing member countries (DMCs) through a 
cohesive approach to implementing the operational plans for Strategy 2030’s seven operational 
priorities.1 The TA will (i) help integrate the operational plans in country partnership strategies 
(CPSs) and projects; (ii) promote innovative knowledge solutions and help develop DMC capacity, 
and (iii) enhance monitoring and reporting of the operational plans. These activities will enable 
ADB to better help DMCs promote more effective, inclusive, and sustainable economic growth.  
 
2.  The TA was endorsed during the corporate priority framework meeting in November 2019 
and is included in the 2020 Management approved results-based work plan of the Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  In October 2019, ADB approved the operational plans for each of the seven operational 
priorities of Strategy 2030.3 The operational plans endeavor to guide ADB operations and offer 
new opportunities to implement Strategy 2030 using integrated and differentiated approaches in 
project  design,  knowledge  work,  and  financing.  ADB  has  not  fully  applied  innovative  and 
integrated  approaches  to  address  key  development  challenges  in  DMCs  because  it  lacks 
upstream analyses and full integration of inter-sectoral and thematic linkages in country strategies 
and project designs. Knowledge gaps also exist because of varying levels of available information 
and capacity within countries and across subregions. DMCs in Asia and the Pacific also face 
serious challenges (paras. 4–13) including the onset of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic. The approval of the Strategy 2030 operational plans marked the beginning of new 
pathways that will allow the ADB to respond effectively to these challenges in Asia and the Pacific. 
This TA will support that response. 
 
4.  The increased challenge and urgency of implementing Strategy 2030 during the 
COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic and necessary measures to control its spread 
have created both a health crisis and massive economic and social shock that threatens to send 
millions into poverty. The course of the pandemic remains highly uncertain, with direct health and 
economic impacts that could last well into 2021, and financial, fiscal, and sectoral impacts that 
could extend into the following years. DMCs will need integrated solutions that can help address 
the extended challenge and ongoing uncertainty. In particular, the CPSs will have to build in new 
development pathways to address the challenges faced by DMCs. This TA will contribute to these 
pathways. 
 
5.  Remaining poverty and inequality in the face of demographic transition. In Asia and 
the Pacific, despite decades of sustained growth and the fact that around 95% of the population 
live in middle-income countries, some 263 million people live below the $1.90 per day poverty 
line, and around 1.1 billion live on less than $3.20 per day.4 Asia and the Pacific is also both the 
youngest and the fastest-aging region of the world. With 2 billion people under age 30 (nearly half 
of the total population), the region requires generation of quality jobs, investments in the future of 
youth, development of human capital, and new forms of social protection to address vulnerabilities

Manila.  https://www.adb.org/about/strategy-2030-operational-priorities

in changing workforces.5 The region is also home to more than half of the world’s population of 
people over age 60 and is expected to be home to nearly two-thirds of the global population over 
the age of 60, or close to 1.3 billion people, by 2050.6 Protection against the risk of poverty in old 
age is strikingly absent for informal sector workers and persons with disabilities. An immediate 
challenge is to develop social protection and health and long-term care systems and services 
(including human resources) that are inclusive, responsive to DMC contexts, affordable, and 
accessible. COVID-19 and the necessary policy response has compounded these challenges, 
straining health care systems, plunging millions more into poverty, requiring mobilization of huge 
social assistance, and severely disrupting education. 
 
6.  Slow progress on gender equality. Despite significant achievements, persistent gender 
gaps remain. In developing countries of Asia and the Pacific, women are on average 30% less 
likely than men to be in the workforce.7 Female labor force participation in the region fell from 56% 
in 1990 to 46% in 2017.8 On average in the region, women earn 77% of men’s wages, but there 
are huge variations across countries and industries.9 Though the region has seen improved trends 
in school enrollment for girls at primary and secondary level, challenges to integrate more young 
girls into science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and information and communication 
technologies still persist. Gender based violence remains a challenge in the region, especially in 
South Asia and the Pacific. Long term lockdowns and quarantines have made gender based 
violence worse during the pandemic, and many women owned and operated small businesses 
have been forced to close or cut back operations. 
 
7.  Increasing environmental degradation and risks and vulnerability to climate change. 
The region’s large and diverse ecosystems sustain livelihoods, support food production, provide 
water  and  energy security,  and  provide  resilience  to  climate  and  disaster risks.  A  sizable 
proportion  of  the  region's  population  still  works  in  agriculture,  fisheries,  and  forestry—the 
productive sectors most at risk from climate change and extreme weather events. The poor are 
particularly vulnerable because they disproportionately rely on ecosystem services for their 
livelihoods and food security. DMCs face growing environmental pressures, including air, land, 
freshwater,  and  marine  pollution;  inadequate  waste  management;  ecosystem  degradation, 
including deforestation and biodiversity loss; and unsustainable resource management practices, 
including unsustainable fishing and groundwater extraction. Climate change is also a major threat 
to sustainability at all levels. Globally about half of all greenhouse gas emissions come from Asia, 
which are set to increase in step with economic growth.10 Many DMCs, particularly low-lying and 
small island developing states, are highly vulnerable to natural hazards and impacts of climate 
change. Disaster losses are growing because of insufficient regard for climate and disaster risk.  
 
8.  Declining livability of growing cities. Urbanization in the region has increased from 
about 20% in the 1950s to about 48% in 2018. By 2030, the share of the urban population is

projected to increase to 55%, with an estimated 2.5 billion people living in cities.11 Furthermore, 
58% of the world’s total slum population, or 597 million people, were living in slums and informal 
settlements in developing Asia in 2018.12 Rapid urbanization brings about opportunities and 
challenges. Population migration from rural to urban areas is often associated with economic 
opportunities, better access to health and education services, and improved living conditions. At 
the same time, cities in the region are growing larger and becoming more difficult to manage; they 
need to reverse environmental degradation and address massive shortfalls in urban infrastructure. 
Cities, especially coastal low-lying ones, are also increasingly vulnerable to natural hazards. 
COVID-19 has caused large financial losses for urban transit systems, lowered municipal tax 
revenues, and raised questions about high density urban living. 
 
9.  Stagnating growth in rural areas. The agriculture and natural resources sectors suffer 
from lagging rural development, inefficient agricultural markets, poor soil and water resources 
management, diminishing youth interest, and climate change impacts. Rural areas still have an 
insufficient number of rural roads, electric grids, and access to basic health, education, water, and 
sanitation. Investments in these areas are often lower compared to urban areas. Insufficient 
agricultural markets result in 30%–40% post-harvest losses and exacerbate the inability of 
smallholders to earn livable incomes. This creates pressure to adopt unsustainable farming 
practices that pollute soil and water resources and leads to over-harvesting of forests and 
fisheries. Increasing numbers of women farmers suffer from limited access to support services 
and agricultural inputs. The impacts of climate change (for example, increased incidences of 
floods and droughts) are causing high production losses and lower yields. 
 
10.  Weaknesses in public sector governance and service delivery. Problems with public 
sector management create serious challenges for DMCs in meeting the Sustainable Development 
Goals. About 350 million people in the region are still without electricity, 600 million lack improved 
sources of drinking water, 1.5 billion lack improved sanitation facilities, and 1 billion live more than 
2 kilometers from an all-season road. Stronger institutional development founded on better quality 
infrastructure, operating in many instances across more effective state-owned enterprises, can 
improve service delivery and value addition. Shortcomings on domestic resource mobilization 
need to be addressed, as tax yields across DMCs average 17% or half of the average of 34% in 
the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The quality and 
outreach of services at the subnational level also need systematic strengthening because local 
governments are responsible for 65% of the 169 Sustainable Development Goal targets. The 
pandemic has put huge pressure on governments to improve service delivery while facing growing 
revenue shortfalls, further weakening debt sustainability in many countries.     
 
11.  Gaps in connectivity, pressure on trade, and insufficient regional public goods. The 
overall level of regional cooperation and integration in Asia and the Pacific has been rising, but 
with varied progress across subregions.13 Large investments are needed to bridge regional 
connectivity gaps (inter-regional and intra-regional), especially in South Asia and Central Asia, by 
building high quality connectivity (including digital connectivity) that will support green recovery, 
incorporate  health  resilience,  and  promote  private  sector  participation  and  private–public 
partnership.14 In the context of a weakened multilateral trade system, it is important to sustain 
Asia’s trade performance by helping new regional trade and investment agreements progress and

helping DMCs take better advantage of trade opportunities. Asia’s growth is increasing stress on 
the environment and causing other risks, requiring increased attention to promoting regional 
public goods. The private sector needs to engage more systematically in the regional cooperation 
and integration agenda. COVID-19 has led to an unprecedented global decline in trade and travel 
and disrupted international financial flows. It has also made regional cooperation on health and 
other areas all the more urgent. 
 
12.  Rapid changes in digital technology. Artificial intelligence, big data, digital platforms, 
and other aspects of the digital transformation will fundamentally alter the way the world lives, 
works, and connects. While it creates new opportunities, it also makes skills development and 
lifelong learning more important, and requires new forms of social protection to address new 
vulnerabilities resulting from the informality, temporality, and mobility of work. Ensuring access to 
affordable digital technology and using it to improve access to and quality of services, including 
improving governance and public administration will be essential to addressing inequality. COVID-
19 has forced millions to work and attend school from home and has made digital connectivity 
and security all the more important.  
 
13.  ADB’s value addition.  Strategy 2030 calls for effectively incorporating inter-sectoral and 
thematic linkages into country strategies and project designs. ADB will need to address potential 
mismatches in response to evolving development challenges, including in sector-silo approaches 
and insufficient evidence-based design and implementation of projects and programs. This TA is 
designed to support the implementation of the Strategy 2030 operational plans by mainstreaming 
them in country programs and project designs to promote integrated approaches and improve 
cost efficiency and effectiveness of ADB projects and programs, ensuring less fragmentation of 
resources and avoiding duplication of effort. Through this TA, ADB will help DMCs (i) address 
their development challenges (paras. 4-13) through improved, demand driven operations; (ii) use 
country-focused and differentiated approaches; (iii) deliver One ADB integrated solutions and 
multisectoral  approaches;  (iv)  promote  innovative  technologies;  (v)  expand  private  sector 
operations; (vi) develop capacity; and (vii) maximize development impacts. The seven Strategy 
2030 operational plans recognize that development challenges are increasingly complex and 
require solutions that are interlinked across themes and sectors. The proposed TA will support 
holistic approaches to strengthen complementarity and reinforce integrated solutions.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
14.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: Results of ADB Strategy 2030 operational 
plans achieved in DMCs.15 The TA will have the following outcome: Integration of innovative 
approaches in development strategies and projects in selected DMCs increased.16 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
15.  The proposed TA will support three outputs, as follows.17 
 
 
15 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
16 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
17  An indicative list of activities, organized by output and operational plan, is in the linked documents.

5 
16.  Output 1: Alignment of country partnership strategies, investment projects, and 
programs  with  Strategy  2030  operational  priorities  improved.  The  TA  should  support 
implementation of the seven operational plans through enhanced technical support and facilitating 
collaboration between operations and knowledge departments. Each operational plan identifies 
(i) strategic priorities to guide ADB operations and (ii) new opportunities to implement Strategy 
2030 through innovative project design, knowledge products and services, and financing products. 
Working with operations departments, the TA will support country-level dialogues with DMC 
government stakeholders to focus ADB assistance in the priority areas of Strategy 2030 and 
identify expertise that may be needed to prepare upstream inter-sectoral analyses and other 
cross-sectoral and thematic work to enhance CPS (building on the Inclusive and Sustainable 
Growth Assessment) and project design. Through these dialogues and in partnership with 
operations departments and the Strategy, Policy, and Partnerships Department (SPD), the TA will 
help sector and thematic experts engage in addressing development challenges (some of which 
are highlighted in paras. 4–13) by promoting more integrated approaches and helping translate 
these approaches in country strategies and project designs. It is expected that this output will help 
at least five CPSs to reflect new approaches derived from new analytical work that can pave the 
way  for  operational  pipelines  that  will  be  country  focused,  promote  the  use  of  innovative 
technologies, and deliver integrated solutions. 
 
17.  Output 2: Innovative knowledge solutions and institutional capacity development 
supported. Working closely with operations departments, the TA will support country-level and 
regional dialogues to identify and increase capacity around areas where knowledge gaps exist 
that the TA support can help close. As with output 1, the rationale section highlights some of the 
key current and emerging issues with limited knowledge bases. The TA will help close knowledge 
gaps in some critical development challenges that confront DMCs and that arise from changing 
socio-economic  and  political  landscapes,  demographic  shifts,  increased  globalization, 
technological  change,  increased  vulnerabilities  to  environmental  risks,  health-related 
emergencies, and natural hazards and climate change, among others. The TA will help develop 
knowledge products and services that will provide upstream analytical support to operations 
departments, including inter-sectoral analyses.  
 
18.  Working with operations departments, the TA will also support capacity building through 
training  and  policy  dialogues  and  will  convene  cross-sector  and  cross-thematic  knowledge 
sharing events to address specific needs of DMCs. This component will include awareness 
campaigns, capacity-building activities, conferences and workshops, and publication of lessons 
learned. The knowledge products will be shared publicly and also disseminated in ADB websites. 
Interventions under the TA will take into account the differentiated approach needed in DMCs, 
including small island developing states and fragile and conflict-affected situations.18 The TA will 
also support opportunities for ADB to engage with citizens, including youth and persons with 
disabilities. 
 
19.  Output 3: Implementation of operational plans monitored and reported. The seven 
operational plans have results frameworks that have been incorporated in the corporate results 
framework. The indicators reflect key development challenges that mirror current and emerging 
issues faced by DMCs. The TA will also help collect and analyze data on some development 
indicators and help prepare monitoring reports for some operational plans. SDCC will work with 
SPD to support data collection and data analysis of some development indicators and preparation 
 
18 This TA will complement activities supported by the ADB corporate TA on Enhancing Differentiated Approaches in 
Context Sensitive Situations approved in June 2020.

6 
of monitoring reports for some operational plans. The TA will also help prepare communication 
plans to better disseminate results to ADB clients and other stakeholders, particularly in DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $4,750,000, to be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF), of which $1,000,000 is from TASF-6 and $3,750,000 
is from TASF-other sources. The key expenditure items are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  ADB will serve as the executing and implementing agency for the TA. The Sector Advisory 
Service Cluster and the Thematic Advisory Service Cluster in SDCC will jointly administer and 
implement the TA. Operational plan leads will work directly with operations departments and 
through  the  sector  and  thematic  group  committees  where  operations  departments  are  all 
represented to ensure that TA activities are demand driven, do not duplicate existing TA activities, 
and address the priorities of operations departments. SDCC will also ensure that consultants and 
activities under this TA are properly coordinated and work together in an integrated fashion. They 
will also work with SPD under output 3. Both the TA annual program and its progress will be 
reviewed every six months by SDCC management and the seven operational plan leads, in 
cooperation with the chiefs of all sector and thematic groups. SDCC will prioritize and finalize TA 
activities that support operations departments after consulting with sector and thematic group 
committees. SDCC will implement country-level activities after securing government concurrence 
from respective DMCs in coordination with operations departments, including with the ADB 
resident missions. The TA implementation period will be 42 months, starting in October 2020. An 
indicative list of activities to be carried out under this TA is in the linked documents.

23.  Consulting services. The TA will require international and national consulting services 
from firms and individuals in various fields relevant to the seven operational plans. The TA will 
finance consulting services, experts’ meetings and workshops, and report preparation. Resource 
persons will be engaged, as needed, to provide qualitative and quantitative inputs supporting and 
supplementing the research required by the TA and the results presented during the workshops 
and meetings with local stakeholders. Output-based or lump sum contracts, indefinite contracts, 
or framework agreements for consulting services will be considered as applicable. ADB will 
engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) 
and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.19 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $4,750,000 on a grant basis for 
Support to the Implementation of Strategy 2030 Operational Plans, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.
